The Back of The Napkin

Roam

Introduction

  1. The merits of drawing
    • Clarify the idea in your own mind
    • Can be created instantly, without the need for technology
    • Can be shared in an open way which invites comments and inspires discussion
    • Speaking directly from the picture avoids the need for relying on notes, bullet points or a script
    • Any problem can be made clearer with a picture, and any picture can be created using the same set of tools and rules

Which problems? Which pictures? And who is we?

  1. Six types of problems
    • Who and what problems â€“ challenges that relate to things, people and roles
    • How much problems â€“ challenges that involve measuring and counting
    • When problems â€“ challenges that relate to scheduling and timing
    • Where problems â€“ challenges that relate to direction and how things fit together
    • How problems â€“ challenges that relate to how things influence one another
    • Why problems â€“ challenges that relate to seeing the bigger picture
  2. Why hand-drawn pictures are great
    • People like seeing other peopleâ€™s pictures â€“ especially hand-drawn images as their spontaneity and roughness make them less intimidating and more inviting; also, being able to see a concept drawn out step-by-step is clearer
    • Hand-drawn images are quick to create and easy to change
    • Computers make it too easy to draw the wrong thing â€“ by forcing us into using generic formats and shapes
  3. Who is involved?
    • All three types of people are useful and important in the process
